items.text: Most of the time I feel sad and downhearted.
items.rationale: Persistent sadness is a core feature of the Depression scale on the MMPI.

items.text: I have lost interest in activities that I used to enjoy.
items.rationale: Anhedonia is a hallmark symptom directly assessed by the Depression scale.

items.text: I often feel that life is not worth living.
items.rationale: Hopelessness and suicidal ideation are key indicators of elevated Depression scores.

items.text: I cry easily and more often than most people I know.
items.rationale: Frequent crying spells are a behavioral manifestation of depressive affect.

items.text: I feel useless and like a burden to others.
items.rationale: Feelings of worthlessness and being a burden are central to depressive cognition.

items.text: I have difficulty making even simple decisions these days.
items.rationale: Indecisiveness and cognitive slowing are well-established features of depression.

items.text: My sleep has been very poor lately—I either can't fall asleep or I wake up too early.
items.rationale: Sleep disturbance, particularly insomnia and early morning awakening, is a classic depressive symptom.

items.text: I feel guilty about things even when others tell me I shouldn't.
items.rationale: Excessive guilt is a cognitive hallmark of depression captured by Scale 2.

items.text: I have very little energy and feel fatigued most of the day.
items.rationale: Psychomotor retardation and fatigue are somatic features of depression.

items.text: The future looks hopeless to me.
items.rationale: Hopelessness about the future is a core cognitive feature of depression.

items.text: I tend to withdraw from friends and family when I'm feeling down.
items.rationale: Social withdrawal during low mood is a behavioral indicator of depression.

items.text: I have trouble concentrating on reading or watching television.
items.rationale: Impaired concentration is a well-documented cognitive symptom of depression.

items.text: I sometimes feel so low that I just stay in bed all day.
items.rationale: Staying in bed could reflect depressive psychomotor retardation but could also indicate fatigue from medical illness (Hypochondriasis).

items.text: I don't seem to care about my appearance the way I used to.
items.rationale: Neglect of grooming is common in depression but can also appear in Schizophrenia-related avolition.

items.text: I prefer to be alone because being around people drains me emotionally.
items.rationale: Social withdrawal and emotional exhaustion from others could map to Depression or Social Introversion.

items.text: I am constantly worried that I have a serious illness that doctors have not yet found.
items.rationale: Preoccupation with undiagnosed serious illness is the defining feature of Scale 1.

items.text: I pay very close attention to every ache and pain in my body.
items.rationale: Somatic hypervigilance is a core characteristic of hypochondriacal concern.

items.text: I frequently visit doctors but they never seem to find anything wrong with me.
items.rationale: Doctor shopping with negative findings is a classic behavioral pattern of hypochondriasis.

items.text: I believe my health is much worse than what most doctors tell me.
items.rationale: Discounting medical reassurance is central to hypochondriacal thinking.

items.text: I spend a lot of time reading about diseases and medical conditions.
items.rationale: Excessive health information seeking reflects somatic preoccupation.

items.text: I often feel numbness or tingling in parts of my body that I can't explain.
items.rationale: Vague somatic complaints without medical explanation are characteristic of Scale 1 elevations.

items.text: My stomach gives me a lot of trouble and I worry it could be something serious.
items.rationale: Gastrointestinal complaints with catastrophic interpretation are typical of hypochondriasis.

items.text: I feel that my body is deteriorating even though tests come back normal.
items.rationale: Conviction of physical decline despite normal findings is a hallmark of hypochondriacal concern.

items.text: I am more aware of my heartbeat than most people seem to be.
items.rationale: Heightened interoceptive awareness is a well-documented feature of somatic preoccupation.

items.text: I often think that a minor symptom could be a sign of cancer or another deadly disease.
items.rationale: Catastrophic misinterpretation of benign symptoms is central to hypochondriasis.

items.text: I have headaches that are so severe I'm sure something must be wrong with my brain.
items.rationale: Somatic symptom with catastrophic attribution is a core feature of Scale 1.

items.text: People close to me say I complain about my health too much.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of excessive health complaints reflects the interpersonal impact of hypochondriasis.

items.text: I sometimes feel weak and dizzy for no apparent reason and it frightens me.
items.rationale: Unexplained somatic symptoms with fear could also reflect Hysteria (conversion symptoms).

items.text: I have trouble sleeping because I keep thinking about what might be wrong with my body.
items.rationale: Insomnia driven by health worry is primarily hypochondriacal but sleep disturbance also loads on Depression.

items.text: When I feel a new pain, I get very anxious and can't stop thinking about it until I see a doctor.
items.rationale: The anxiety and rumination component could map to Psychasthenia, though the somatic focus is hypochondriacal.

items.text: I have so many ideas racing through my head that I can barely keep up with them.
items.rationale: Racing thoughts and flight of ideas are cardinal features of hypomanic states assessed by Scale 9.

items.text: I often take on more projects than I can realistically handle because I feel so energized.
items.rationale: Overcommitment driven by elevated energy is a classic behavioral manifestation of hypomania.

items.text: People have told me that I talk too fast and jump from topic to topic.
items.rationale: Pressured speech and tangentiality are well-established features of hypomanic presentation.

items.text: I need much less sleep than other people and still feel full of energy.
items.rationale: Decreased need for sleep with sustained energy is a defining feature of hypomania.

items.text: I sometimes spend money impulsively on things I don't really need.
items.rationale: Impulsive spending reflects the poor judgment and grandiosity associated with hypomanic states.

items.text: I feel like I can accomplish anything I set my mind to, no matter how ambitious.
items.rationale: Grandiose self-confidence is a core cognitive feature of hypomania.

items.text: I get restless very easily and have a hard time sitting still.
items.rationale: Psychomotor agitation and restlessness are hallmark features of elevated Scale 9.

items.text: I tend to act on impulse without thinking about the consequences.
items.rationale: Impulsivity and poor consequential thinking are characteristic of hypomanic behavior.

items.text: My mood can shift from extremely happy to very irritable within a short period.
items.rationale: Mood lability with irritability is a well-documented feature of hypomanic episodes.

items.text: I often feel a surge of excitement and energy that others around me don't seem to share.
items.rationale: Elevated mood and energy disproportionate to the situation is characteristic of hypomania.

items.text: I frequently start new hobbies or interests but lose interest in them quickly.
items.rationale: Rapid cycling of interests reflects the distractibility and novelty-seeking of hypomania.

items.text: I have been told that I am the life of the party and that my energy is contagious.
items.rationale: Social exuberance and infectious energy are interpersonal manifestations of hypomanic states.

items.text: I sometimes feel so wired that my thoughts seem to come faster than I can speak them.
items.rationale: While racing thoughts are hypomanic, the 'wired' quality could also reflect anxiety (Psychasthenia).

items.text: I get bored very easily and constantly need new stimulation.
items.rationale: Low boredom threshold could reflect hypomania but also Psychopathic Deviate's need for excitement.

items.text: I sometimes do risky things just for the thrill of it, like driving too fast or making reckless bets.
items.rationale: Risk-taking and thrill-seeking could map to Hypomania or Psychopathic Deviate.

items.text: I sometimes lose feeling in my hands or feet and doctors can't find a medical reason.
items.rationale: Unexplained sensory loss (conversion symptom) is a defining feature of Scale 3.

items.text: I tend to deal with stress by developing physical symptoms rather than feeling emotionally upset.
items.rationale: Somatization of psychological distress is the central mechanism of hysteria.

items.text: I have had episodes where I suddenly couldn't see clearly, even though my eyes are fine.
items.rationale: Conversion blindness or visual disturbance without organic cause is a classic hysterical symptom.

items.text: People describe me as someone who is very sociable and eager to please others.
items.rationale: Superficial sociability and need for approval are personality features associated with elevated Scale 3.

items.text: I tend to avoid conflict at all costs and would rather pretend everything is fine.
items.rationale: Denial and conflict avoidance are core defense mechanisms in the hysterical personality style.

items.text: Under stress, I have experienced paralysis in a limb that doctors say has no physical cause.
items.rationale: Conversion paralysis is a prototypical symptom of hysteria.

items.text: I have a strong need to be liked and admired by everyone around me.
items.rationale: Excessive need for social approval is a personality characteristic associated with Scale 3.

items.text: I sometimes have difficulty swallowing even though there is nothing physically wrong with my throat.
items.rationale: Globus hystericus (psychogenic dysphagia) is a classic conversion symptom.

items.text: I tend to use dramatic expressions of emotion to get attention or sympathy from others.
items.rationale: Dramatic emotionality and attention-seeking are interpersonal features of the hysterical style.

items.text: I often feel physical pain during emotionally stressful situations that goes away when the stress passes.
items.rationale: Stress-contingent somatic symptoms reflect the conversion mechanism central to Scale 3.

items.text: I am generally naive about other people's motives and tend to see the best in everyone.
items.rationale: Psychological naivety and denial of hostility in others are characteristic of the hysterical cognitive style.

items.text: I have had episodes of shaking or trembling that seem to come on during times of emotional distress.
items.rationale: Psychogenic tremor is a well-documented conversion symptom.

items.text: I sometimes get unexplained stomach cramps or nausea when I'm under pressure.
items.rationale: Stress-related GI symptoms could reflect Hysteria's somatization or Hypochondriasis's somatic focus.

items.text: I find it very hard to express anger directly, so I tend to bottle it up inside.
items.rationale: Suppression of anger is characteristic of Hysteria but could also relate to Social Introversion.

items.text: I worry a lot about my health and frequently notice physical symptoms that seem to come and go.
items.rationale: Fluctuating somatic symptoms with health worry could map to Hysteria or Hypochondriasis.

items.text: I am more interested in art, music, and literature than most men I know.
items.rationale: Aesthetic interests diverging from traditional masculine norms are a core component of Scale 5.

items.text: I am very sensitive to the feelings and emotions of people around me.
items.rationale: Emotional sensitivity and empathy are features associated with elevated Scale 5 in males.

items.text: I enjoy activities that are traditionally associated with the opposite gender.
items.rationale: Cross-gender interest patterns are directly assessed by the Masculinity-Femininity scale.

items.text: I would rather read poetry than watch a competitive sporting event.
items.rationale: Preference for aesthetic over competitive activities reflects non-traditional gender role interests.

items.text: I find myself deeply moved by beautiful things in nature or art.
items.rationale: Aesthetic sensitivity is a well-established component of Scale 5.

items.text: I have always been more comfortable expressing my emotions than most people of my gender.
items.rationale: Emotional expressiveness diverging from gender norms is central to Scale 5.

items.text: I dislike rough or aggressive activities and prefer gentler pursuits.
items.rationale: Aversion to aggression and preference for gentle activities reflects non-traditional masculine interests.

items.text: I have a strong interest in cooking, interior design, or fashion.
items.rationale: Interest in traditionally feminine domestic and aesthetic domains is assessed by Scale 5.

items.text: I often feel that I don't fit in with others of my own gender.
items.rationale: Gender role alienation is a psychological experience associated with elevated Scale 5.

items.text: I tend to be more nurturing and caregiving than is typical for my gender.
items.rationale: Nurturing tendencies diverging from gender expectations are captured by Scale 5.

items.text: I have always been curious about and open to exploring different ways of expressing my identity.
items.rationale: Openness to non-traditional identity expression is consistent with Scale 5 content.

items.text: I would describe myself as more passive than assertive in most situations.
items.rationale: Passivity versus assertiveness is a dimension captured by the Masculinity-Femininity scale.

items.text: I sometimes feel uncomfortable in situations that require me to act tough or competitive.
items.rationale: Discomfort with competitive demands could reflect Scale 5 or Social Introversion.

items.text: I tend to avoid confrontation and prefer to resolve disagreements through compromise.
items.rationale: Conflict avoidance could reflect Scale 5 passivity or Hysteria's denial of aggression.

items.text: I have never been interested in traditionally masculine hobbies like hunting, mechanics, or contact sports.
items.rationale: Lack of interest in masculine activities could reflect Scale 5 or Social Introversion's general disengagement.

items.text: I am certain that people are plotting against me behind my back.
items.rationale: Persecutory ideation is the defining feature of Scale 6.

items.text: I often feel that others are watching me and talking about me when I'm not around.
items.rationale: Ideas of reference and surveillance are core paranoid symptoms.

items.text: I find it very difficult to trust other people, even those who are close to me.
items.rationale: Pervasive mistrust is a central feature of paranoid thinking assessed by Scale 6.

items.text: I believe that most people will take advantage of you if you give them the chance.
items.rationale: Cynical mistrust and expectation of exploitation are characteristic of paranoid ideation.

items.text: When something goes wrong in my life, I suspect that someone has deliberately caused it.
items.rationale: External attribution of negative events to deliberate sabotage is a hallmark of paranoia.

items.text: I am very sensitive to criticism and tend to hold grudges for a long time.
items.rationale: Hypersensitivity to criticism and grudge-holding are well-established paranoid personality features.

items.text: I often feel that I am being treated unfairly by the system or by people in authority.
items.rationale: Perceived injustice and persecution by authority figures are core paranoid themes.

items.text: I have to be on guard at all times because people are trying to undermine me.
items.rationale: Hypervigilance driven by persecutory beliefs is a defining feature of paranoia.

items.text: I suspect that my coworkers or neighbors have been spreading lies about me.
items.rationale: Suspicion of defamation by known others is a classic paranoid concern.

items.text: I often read hidden meanings or threats into innocent remarks made by others.
items.rationale: Misinterpretation of benign stimuli as threatening is a core cognitive feature of paranoia.

items.text: I feel that I have been singled out for mistreatment that others don't have to endure.
items.rationale: Perception of unique victimization is characteristic of paranoid thinking.

items.text: I question the loyalty of my friends and wonder if they are truly on my side.
items.rationale: Doubting the loyalty of close others is a well-documented paranoid feature.

items.text: I sometimes feel that people are laughing at me even when there's no obvious reason.
items.rationale: Ideas of reference involving ridicule are paranoid but could also reflect social anxiety (Social Introversion).

items.text: I get angry quickly when I feel someone is disrespecting me.
items.rationale: Anger in response to perceived disrespect is paranoid but could also reflect Psychopathic Deviate's hostility.

items.text: I sometimes hear people saying my name when no one is actually talking to me.
items.rationale: Auditory misperceptions with paranoid content could map to Paranoia or Schizophrenia.

items.text: I am plagued by unwanted thoughts that I cannot seem to get out of my head.
items.rationale: Intrusive, ego-dystonic thoughts are the hallmark of obsessional thinking assessed by Scale 7.

items.text: I feel compelled to check things repeatedly, like whether I locked the door or turned off the stove.
items.rationale: Compulsive checking behavior is a classic manifestation of psychasthenia.

items.text: I worry excessively about things that most people would consider trivial.
items.rationale: Excessive worry disproportionate to the situation is a core feature of Scale 7.

items.text: I have irrational fears that I know don't make sense but I can't seem to control them.
items.rationale: Ego-dystonic phobias and irrational fears are directly assessed by the Psychasthenia scale.

items.text: I often feel tense and anxious without any clear reason.
items.rationale: Free-floating anxiety is a central feature of psychasthenia.

items.text: I have rigid routines that I feel I must follow or something bad will happen.
items.rationale: Ritualistic behavior driven by magical thinking is characteristic of obsessive-compulsive features on Scale 7.

items.text: I ruminate endlessly about past mistakes and things I should have done differently.
items.rationale: Ruminative self-criticism is a well-documented cognitive feature of psychasthenia.

items.text: I have difficulty making decisions because I am afraid of making the wrong choice.
items.rationale: Decisional anxiety driven by fear of error is characteristic of psychasthenic doubt.

items.text: I feel a constant sense of dread, as if something terrible is about to happen.
items.rationale: Chronic apprehensive expectation is a core anxiety feature of Scale 7.

items.text: I am a perfectionist to the point where it interferes with getting things done.
items.rationale: Maladaptive perfectionism is a well-established feature of psychasthenia.

items.text: I often feel overwhelmed by my own thoughts and unable to quiet my mind.
items.rationale: Cognitive flooding and inability to control mental activity are characteristic of Scale 7.

items.text: I have a strong need to count things or arrange objects in a particular order.
items.rationale: Counting and ordering compulsions are classic obsessive-compulsive features of psychasthenia.

items.text: I feel restless and on edge most of the time, as though I can never fully relax.
items.rationale: Chronic restlessness could reflect psychasthenic anxiety or hypomanic agitation.

items.text: I often doubt myself and second-guess my actions even after I've made a decision.
items.rationale: Self-doubt is characteristic of psychasthenia but could also reflect depressive low self-esteem.

items.text: I feel so anxious sometimes that I can't concentrate on anything and feel like I'm falling apart.
items.rationale: Severe anxiety with depersonalization-like experiences could map to Psychasthenia or Schizophrenia.

items.text: I have a hard time following rules that I think are stupid or pointless.
items.rationale: Authority conflict and rejection of social norms are core features of Scale 4.

items.text: I have been in trouble with the law more than once.
items.rationale: Repeated legal difficulties are a behavioral indicator of psychopathic deviance.

items.text: I often lie or manipulate others to get what I want without feeling guilty about it.
items.rationale: Deception and manipulation without remorse are hallmark features of Scale 4.

items.text: My family relationships have always been troubled and full of conflict.
items.rationale: Family discord is a major content area of the Psychopathic Deviate scale.

items.text: I get bored easily and need constant excitement to feel alive.
items.rationale: Low frustration tolerance and need for stimulation are characteristic of psychopathic deviance.

items.text: I don't feel much remorse when I hurt someone's feelings.
items.rationale: Lack of empathy and remorse are defining features of Scale 4.

items.text: I have had many conflicts with authority figures throughout my life.
items.rationale: Chronic authority conflict is a well-established feature of psychopathic deviance.

items.text: I tend to blame others for my problems rather than taking responsibility.
items.rationale: Externalization of blame is a core defense mechanism in psychopathic deviance.

items.text: I have used alcohol or drugs to excess without caring about the consequences.
items.rationale: Substance abuse with disregard for consequences is commonly associated with elevated Scale 4.

items.text: I feel alienated from society and don't really care about fitting in.
items.rationale: Social alienation and rejection of conventional values are central to Scale 4.

items.text: I have stolen things from stores or other people without feeling bad about it.
items.rationale: Theft without guilt is a behavioral manifestation of antisocial features on Scale 4.

items.text: People who know me well would say I can be charming but also very selfish.
items.rationale: Superficial charm combined with selfishness is a classic interpersonal pattern of psychopathic deviance.

items.text: I often feel angry and resentful toward the world for no specific reason.
items.rationale: Free-floating hostility is common in Scale 4 but could also reflect Paranoia.

items.text: I have difficulty maintaining long-term relationships because I get restless and want something new.
items.rationale: Relationship instability could reflect Scale 4's shallow attachments or Hypomania's restlessness.

items.text: I feel that society's rules are designed to control people and I refuse to be controlled.
items.rationale: Anti-authority sentiment could map to Psychopathic Deviate or Paranoia's persecution beliefs.

items.text: I sometimes hear voices that other people cannot hear.
items.rationale: Auditory hallucinations are a cardinal psychotic symptom assessed by Scale 8.

items.text: I often feel that my thoughts are being controlled by an outside force.
items.rationale: Thought control delusions are a first-rank symptom of schizophrenia captured by Scale 8.

items.text: I frequently feel disconnected from my own body, as if I am watching myself from the outside.
items.rationale: Depersonalization is a dissociative experience commonly associated with elevated Scale 8.

items.text: My thinking often feels confused and fragmented, like my thoughts don't connect properly.
items.rationale: Thought disorganization and loosening of associations are core features of schizophrenic cognition.

items.text: I have had experiences that I believe are supernatural or that others would find very strange.
items.rationale: Unusual perceptual experiences and magical thinking are characteristic of Scale 8.

items.text: I sometimes feel that the world around me is not real, like I'm living in a dream.
items.rationale: Derealization is a dissociative symptom commonly associated with schizophrenic-spectrum experiences.

items.text: I feel profoundly different from other people, as if I am a completely different kind of being.
items.rationale: Profound social alienation and feelings of being fundamentally different are core Scale 8 features.

items.text: I have beliefs that others consider bizarre, but I know they are true.
items.rationale: Fixed unusual beliefs (delusions) are a defining feature of schizophrenic thinking.

items.text: I sometimes see things that other people tell me are not there.
items.rationale: Visual hallucinations are a psychotic symptom assessed by Scale 8.

items.text: I have difficulty telling the difference between what is real and what I might be imagining.
items.rationale: Impaired reality testing is a fundamental feature of schizophrenic-spectrum pathology.

items.text: I often feel that parts of my body are changing shape or size in strange ways.
items.rationale: Somatic delusions and body image distortions are characteristic of Scale 8.

items.text: I have had the experience of my thoughts being broadcast so that others can hear them.
items.rationale: Thought broadcasting is a Schneiderian first-rank symptom directly relevant to Scale 8.

items.text: I often feel emotionally flat, as if I can't feel happiness or sadness the way I used to.
items.rationale: Flat affect is characteristic of schizophrenia but emotional blunting can also occur in severe Depression.

items.text: I have trouble organizing my thoughts well enough to carry on a normal conversation.
items.rationale: Disorganized speech could reflect schizophrenic thought disorder or severe anxiety (Psychasthenia).

items.text: I feel completely isolated from other people, as if there is an invisible wall between us.
items.rationale: Profound social isolation could map to Schizophrenia's alienation or Social Introversion.

items.text: I feel very uncomfortable in large social gatherings and try to avoid them whenever possible.
items.rationale: Avoidance of social gatherings is a core behavioral indicator of Scale 0.

items.text: I much prefer spending time alone or with one close friend rather than in a group.
items.rationale: Preference for solitude or dyadic interaction over group settings is central to Social Introversion.

items.text: I find it very difficult to start conversations with people I don't know well.
items.rationale: Difficulty initiating social contact is a well-established feature of Scale 0.

items.text: I am often described by others as shy, quiet, or reserved.
items.rationale: Third-person descriptions of shyness and reserve directly reflect social introversion.

items.text: I feel anxious and self-conscious when I am the center of attention.
items.rationale: Self-consciousness and anxiety in the spotlight are characteristic of elevated Scale 0.

items.text: I rarely volunteer to speak up in meetings or group discussions.
items.rationale: Reluctance to participate verbally in groups is a behavioral manifestation of social introversion.

items.text: I find social events exhausting and need a lot of time alone afterward to recover.
items.rationale: Social fatigue and need for recovery time are hallmark experiences of introverts.

items.text: I have very few close friends and I am content with that.
items.rationale: Small social network with contentment reflects the preference pattern of Scale 0.

items.text: I tend to keep my thoughts and feelings to myself rather than sharing them with others.
items.rationale: Emotional and cognitive privacy is a core feature of social introversion.

items.text: I would rather communicate by email or text than have a face-to-face conversation.
items.rationale: Preference for indirect communication reflects avoidance of direct social interaction.

items.text: I dread having to make small talk with acquaintances or strangers.
items.rationale: Aversion to superficial social interaction is a well-documented feature of Scale 0.

items.text: I have turned down social invitations many times because I would rather stay home.
items.rationale: Behavioral avoidance of social opportunities is a direct indicator of social introversion.

items.text: I feel like I never know what to say in social situations and worry about saying the wrong thing.
items.rationale: Social anxiety with worry about performance could reflect Scale 0 or Psychasthenia's anxious rumination.

items.text: I often feel lonely even though I choose to spend most of my time alone.
items.rationale: Loneliness despite chosen isolation could reflect Social Introversion or Depression's social withdrawal.

items.text: I avoid social situations because I'm afraid people will judge me negatively.
items.rationale: Fear of negative evaluation could map to Social Introversion or Paranoia's interpersonal suspiciousness.
